notes_translated.fr-t-en: Cette statistique officielle de l'Alberta utilise un indice d'état des installations prolongé de cinq ans pour rendre compte de l'état physique des installations appartenant au gouvernement ou soutenues par le gouvernement. L'ICF a été adopté comme mesure commune pour améliorer les rapports en permettant au ministère de l'Infrastructure de comparer les cotes d'état des différents types d'établissements (établissements de santé, écoles, établissements d'enseignement postsecondaire et établissements publics). L'ICM est un rapport du coût pour répondre aux besoins d'entretien actuels et futurs (cinq ans) par rapport à la valeur de remplacement de l'installation. Les FCI sont traduits en bonnes, moyennes et mauvaises notes sur la base de l'"interprétation des valeurs FCI" indiquée ci-dessous. Les pourcentages sont calculés en prenant les mètres carrés de toutes les installations en bon, moyen ou mauvais état (tel que défini par FCI) et en divisant chacun par la superficie totale de tous les bâtiments de chaque type d'installation.
notes_translated.en: This Alberta Official Statistic uses a 5-year extended Facility Condition Index (FCI) value to report the physical condition of government owned or supported facilities. The FCI was adopted as a common measure to enhance reporting by enabling the Ministry of Infrastructure to compare condition ratings across facility types (health facilities, schools, post-secondary institutions and government owned facilities). The FCI is a ratio of the cost to address current and future (five year) maintenance needs, relative to facility replacement value. FCI’s are translated to good, fair and poor ratings based on the “interpretation of FCI Values” stated below. The percentages are calculated by taking the square metres of all facilities in good, fair or poor condition (as defined by FCI) and dividing each by the total area of all buildings within each facility type.

The FCI was adopted as a common measure to enhance reporting by enabling the Ministry of Infrastructure to compare condition ratings across facility types (health facilities, schools, post-secondary institutions and government owned facilities). The FCI is a ratio of the cost to address current and future (five year) maintenance needs, relative to facility replacement value. FCI’s are translated to good, fair and poor ratings based on the “interpretation of FCI Values” stated below. The percentages are calculated by taking the square metres of all facilities in good, fair or poor condition (as defined by FCI) and dividing each by the total area of all buildings within each facility type.
